hints_html:
Recall the Taylor series expansion for \(\sin(x)\), \(\cos(x)\), and \(e^x\).

\[\begin{aligned} \sin x &= \sum^{\infty}_{n=0} \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1)!} x^{2n+1} = x - \frac{x^3}{3!} + \frac{x^5}{5!} - \cdots\quad\text{ for all } x\!\\ \cos x &= \sum^{\infty}_{n=0} \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n)!} x^{2n} = 1 - \frac{x^2}{2!} + \frac{x^4}{4!} - \cdots\quad\text{ for all } x\! \\ e^{x} &= \sum^{\infty}_{n=0} \frac{x^n}{n!} = 1 + x + \frac{x^2}{2!} + \cdots\quad\text{ for all } x\! \end{aligned}\]
hints_latex: Recall the Taylor series expansion for $\sin(x)$, $\cos(x)$, and $e^x$.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Following the hints we can just plug in the argument of the functions and calculate

\[\begin{aligned} \sin (x^3) &= x^3 - \frac{x^9}{3!} + \frac{x^{15}}{5!} - \cdots \\ \cos (x^{3/2}) &= 1 - \frac{x^3}{2!} + \frac{x^6}{4!} - \cdots \\ \cos (x) &= 1 - \frac{x^2}{2!} + \frac{x^4}{4!} - \cdots \\ \cos (x^3) &= 1 - \frac{x^6}{2!} + \frac{x^{12}}{4!} - \cdots \\ e^{x^3} &= 1 + x^3 + \frac{x^6}{2!} + \cdots\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the correct answer is v.

A clever way of doing this problem is to consider the following:

  • \(S_3(0) = 1\), hence the candidate function needs to also satisfy this condition. Since \(\sin(0) = 0 \not= 1\), choice i. can be eliminated.

  • \(S_3\) is increasing for small positive values of x, since, for small x, the term x3 dominates. In particular, \(S_3(x) > 1\) for small positive values of x. But since the cosine is decreasing for small positive values of x, and can also never be more than 1, the choices ii, iii, and iv can all be eliminated.

  • This only leaves v. Notice that this choice makes sense

    \[\begin{aligned} e^0 = 0,\end{aligned}\]

    and \(e^{x^3}\) is increasing.
sols_latex:
A clever way of doing this problem is to consider the following:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $S_3(0) = 1$, hence the candidate function needs to also satisfy this
  condition. Since $\sin(0) = 0 \not= 1$, choice \emph{i.} can be
  eliminated.
\item
  $S_3$ is increasing for small positive values of \emph{x}, since, for
  small \emph{x}, the term \emph{x\textsuperscript{3}} dominates. In
  particular, $S_3(x) > 1$ for small positive values of \emph{x}. But
  since the cosine is decreasing for small positive values of \emph{x},
  and can also never be more than \emph{1}, the choices \emph{ii},
  \emph{iii}, and \emph{iv} can all be eliminated.
\item
  This only leaves \emph{v.} Notice that this choice makes
  sense\begin{align*}
e^0 = 0,
\end{align*} and $e^{x^3}$ is increasing.
\end{itemize}
sols_raw:
Following the hints we can just plug in the argument of the functions and calculate
:<math>\begin{align}
\sin (x^3) &= x^3 - \frac{x^9}{3!} + \frac{x^{15}}{5!} - \cdots \\
\cos (x^{3/2}) &= 1 - \frac{x^3}{2!} + \frac{x^6}{4!} - \cdots \\
\cos (x) &= 1 - \frac{x^2}{2!} + \frac{x^4}{4!} - \cdots \\
\cos (x^3) &= 1 - \frac{x^6}{2!} + \frac{x^{12}}{4!} - \cdots \\
e^{x^3} &= 1 + x^3 + \frac{x^6}{2!} + \cdots
\end{align}
</math>

Hence, the correct answer is ''v.''
A clever way of doing this problem is to consider the following:

* <math>S_3(0) = 1</math>, hence the candidate function needs to also satisfy this condition. Since <math>\sin(0) = 0 \not= 1</math>, choice ''i.'' can be eliminated.
* <math>S_3</math> is increasing for small positive values of ''x'', since, for small ''x'', the term ''x<sup>3</sup>'' dominates. In particular, <math>S_3(x) > 1</math> for small positive values of ''x''. But since the cosine is decreasing for small positive values of ''x'', and can also never be more than ''1'', the choices ''ii'', ''iii'', and ''iv'' can all be eliminated.
* This only leaves ''v.'' Notice that this choice makes sense: <math>e^0 = 0</math>, and <math>e^{x^3}</math> is increasing.
statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this question.

The expression

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle S_3 = 1+x^3+\frac{x^6}2\end{aligned}\]

is the first three terms of a Taylor series for:

\[\begin{aligned} \textit{i. }\quad &\sin(x^3)\\ \textit{ii. }\quad &\cos(x^{\frac32})\\ \textit{iii. }\quad &\cos(x)\\ \textit{iv. }\quad &\cos(x^3)\\ \textit{v. }\quad &e^{x^3} \end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
''Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this question.''

The expression
:<math>\displaystyle S_3 = 1+x^3+\frac{x^6}2</math>
is the first three terms of a Taylor series for:

:<math>\displaystyle \begin{align} \textit{i. }\quad &\sin(x^3)\\
\textit{ii. }\quad &\cos(x^{\frac32})\\
\textit{iii. }\quad &\cos(x)\\
\textit{iv. }\quad &\cos(x^3)\\
\textit{v. }\quad &e^{x^3} \end{align}</math>
